description: Wow!... the caprese and egg breakfast sandwich is Delicious and affordable under 6$!! Such a hard combination to find!  Egg, a generous  amount of fresh mozzarella, roasted tomato, arugula, pesto, on lightly toasted seeded bread... I don't usually eat bread but this sandwich is great if your looking for something affordable... free refillable coffee... and the nicest lady works hard and is so so so friendly...  the place has room to sit with tables... light faint music in the back round.... nothing fancy but my new go to for a little coffee and breakfast..
author: Sam E.

description: The cappuccino wasn't sweet which I liked. I didn't try the food so this review is only for the cappuccino and the service. The service was great, quick and attentive. The cappuccino was good not great and not anything I'd recommend, just a no frills cappuccino
author: Rey L.

description: They never have the Oatmeal and Almond packaged cookies that everyone likes and are in demand! I have been to this location several times and they never have what you want. Disappointed in customer service!
author: Alex U.

description: I like this place and their sandwiches were okay but you really have to pay attention and OPEN your sandwich and check it before you walk out if you're taking it to go.  Quite a few times, I got a wrong order or someone else's order and last week, 10/10, I paid for a full farmer's chicken sandwich but instead got a light (smaller cheaper size portion) sandwich and the chicken mix had 3 pieces of cartilage AND a chicken bone o_O  If I wasn't further away, I would of come back and ask for a refund. This was a bad experience and I don't think I will order sandwiches from this place again. They change their staff quiet frequently and I'm sure that's the problem why so many errors happen.
author: Natalie G.

description:
We live in a city where $12 sandwiches are king and chain restaurants are universally abhorred. 

But don't you dare turn your nose up at Grain D'Or because this neighborhood bakery (an offshoot of Andersen Bakery), with its sterile, unexciting decor and strangely sultry KOIT 96.5 knockoff music, will serve you the most unassuming sandwich ever that will keep you full for hours... for $7.50 or so.

Yeah, whatever, I like Ike's sandwiches just as much as the next pretentious San Franciscan, but I always feel disgusting after eating them and must temporarily adopt a very sedentary lifestyle in order to recover. I love getting the chicken & avocado sandwich on a baguette here (but you have a plethora of breads to choose from!), even though the size of the sandwich was pretty underwhelming during my first visit. Sure, the sandwiches here pale in comparison to Ike's hearty sandwiches, but Grain D'Or does not skimp on the avocado. The pesto mayo on the chicken & avocado is heavenly. And I don't even like basil, but I loved this flavor combination.

I haven't tried any of the bread here, but I've seen plenty of people purchase freshly baked loaves. The cinnamon danish twists were a perfect post-lunch snack and not too sweet either. Service was incredibly friendly.
author: Amy C.

description:
What is going on here? They display their kouign-amann pastries upside down! When I asked an employee about it, they insisted that the flat bottom with the almonds was correct. Not the pretty, flaky, folded side? Then when I saw the same thing happening at an Andersen Bakery elsewhere... I was blown away. Andersen and Grain D'or are from the same company, so is this a company-wide policy? I've contacted them. This concerns me. 

The pastries were a bit on the dry side for me. Aesthetically they are cute.
author: Thien H.

description: I went here because I'm a huge fan of Andersen bakery. I went on a Sunday afternoon so there wasn't much left but they still had cruffins which is what I was looking for. I got the coffee cream cruffin ($2.75). It was so good! This one had a lot of cream and it was soft and fairly fresh. Good service too! I'll definitely come back but earlier so I can get the best pick!
author: Regina W.

description:
When is an Andersen's Bakery not an Andersen's Bakery? When it's a Grain D'Or, I guess. I tried to find evidence of their merger, but strangely there's absolutely nothing about it if when you Google it. It's like a bad TV-movie from the 1970's when the first wife goes missing and the suspicious husband is suddenly married to the high school Lolita who has assumed the first wife's name. I think it starred Bill Bixby and Barbara Eden. OK, I made that up. But it is strange since they have almost identical menus. Oh, who cares? My focus was getting something to eat before venturing deeper into the Marina on a brisk Saturday morning.

Even for a weekend, I tried to be good and ordered the $6.75 Vegetarian Feast, a crusty sandwich slathered with Dijon mustard and mayo with lettuce, sprouts, tomato, cucumber, fresh avocado, and provolone cheese (photo: http://bit.ly/2dli3Qq). It was pretty good, fresh and just like the one I usually get at Andersen's, so I wasn't disappointed. Alas, sitting in there was probably a mistake because I weakened and bought a $2.50 Almond Cheese Bun which I devoured in a nanosecond (photo: http://bit.ly/2cvoH4S). So even if it was an Andersen's Bakery in disguise, this quick stop certainly met my carb-infused needs.

FOOD - 3 stars...a veggie sandwich that met my momentary detour into good dietary sense
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...gee, it sure feels like an Andersen's Bakery
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...merely serviceable
TOTAL - 3 stars...a quick bite that works in a pinch on Clement
author: Ed U.

description:
I visit Clement Street for their variety of Asian foods for lunch and dinner, often when having an excuse to drive into the city. Today my girlfriend and her mom had hair appointment plans in the morning so I thought it would be a good idea to find a cafe with Internet access while I wait. I had to do some online study for work anyway. 

Using my trusty app I found two cafes nearby the hair salon. It was either Cumaica or Grain D'Or. Cumaica sounded like a nice small coffee shop, but too small if I wanted to linger for a couple hours. So I wandered a few steps over to Grain D'Or. What a pleasant surprise. 

There was plenty of space, nice comfy bench seats and speedy and most importantly reliable Wi-Fi Internet access. The employees work hard, and I often see them running (literally) back and forth to clean up vacated tables and drop off caffeinated drinks. 

They have fresh baked goods, including pasteries and breads. I got the blueberry muffin. It was nicely sweetened with fresh blueberries and crumbles on top. I needed a 'pick me up' so I ordered the iced coffee. It is not anything fancy, but you can tell it was freshly made and brewed without that burnt taste I get at many coffee shops. It was a very good compliment to my muffin when washed down together. Mmm. The simple things in life. 

After a couple hours of interrupted study thanks to me having Facebook running in the background, I got a good study session in, and my ladies look good with their new 'do'. Highly recommended for a nice stay in an unpretentious coffee shop in the middle of a busy Clement Street neighborhood.
author: David K.

description:
The rain broke, and we headed out for a few errands. This was the kind of day where precision and focus reigned supreme, far outweighing those inner desires to both dilly and dally. On a street where distractions could reign supreme (what's with all the local gift shops and bookstores popping up, not that I'm complaining) it was a day for getting stuff done, and doing it quickly.

We thought this was the perfect lunch. Pop in for a quick bite, and get back out to the garden center, zip across town for more errands, and try to avoid the rain along the way.

It was promising to begin with. We had a short line. We made up our minds, and ordered from the new guy at the register. I cut him some slack, because he was clearly new, but it wasn't exactly the model of efficiency we'd hoped for. Still, a couple of sandwiches and a kouign amann were on their way.

It was another slightly longer wait, and our food was ready. We got the kouign amann at the counter, actually, and waited for sandwiches. I had high hopes for the blueberry pastry, but it lacked the depth, development, and both the butter softness or outer crunch that make this pastry so special. I'd skip it next time.

The sandwiches came, and I scarfed down the turkey avocado. It's not fresh turkey breast, it's sliced deli meat. So, it's fine. The BLT across the table looked like a better order, and I'm told it was. 

Not exactly the zippy service we'd hoped for, nor the deliciously satisfying lunch. But hardly a disappointment in the big picture. It's a solid stop. Fine. Satisfactory. No complaints here.
author: Jeffrey S.

description: I've been meaning to write a review for this lovely bakery/cafe for awhile.  This place has such amazing treats.  The tropical fruit flan, eclairs, almond croissants and saffron twists are some of my favorites.  The staff is always friendly and attentive.  My only complaint is that getting a sandwich to go always seems to take a while.  It doesn't prevent me from going.  The baked goods are so delectable and the space itself is warm and inviting.  The exterior has a Parisian charm that is a great accent to busy Clement Street.  If you have a sweet tooth or want a good loaf of bread look no further.
author: Kim P.

description: This place was our impromptu breakfast stop on our holiday in the city. We had THE best sausage breakfast sandwich and bacon roll to share (which the women cut in half so thoughtfully). The soy laté was made incredibly well- full body flavor and smooth. We had a great experience there on a quiet Monday morning before we headed to Baker Beach.  I gave them 4 stars only because they were short staffed and there was a small wait time for the customers waiting which I think could have been handled more efficiently.
author: Kimberly P.

description: Friendly staff. Great sandwiches, perhaps a bit more expensive than Safeway or CalMart but the bread is top notch, very fresh.
author: Melissa C.

description:
Just walked in on a whim, (the sandwich picture of a Bacon Roll caught my eye) while in the neighborhood shopping at SLOAT Garden Nursery.
Immediately struck by how clean the place "FELT" 
Bacon Roll      YUM!!  
Salt sticks, croissants. YUM!

Very impressed and very reasonable
author: Glen B.

description: The other morning, I met a friend here and we had tea and pastries. We shared their saffron raisin twist and mango pastry -- wow -- the hint of saffron was definitely a welcome twist on the classic recipe, not too sweet, flaky, fresh, perfect. And the mango pastry was to die for -- it tasted like someone just picked the mango off the tree, the unique aromatic taste of mango lifted my senses, again in a flaky fresh pastry shell. Delightful.
author: Art I.

description: I always come here every Sunday when I can in the morning!  they're amazing workers and Sue is a very sweet lady.  the food here is really good and the tea's are excellent as well!
author: Quin G.

description: Stopped by here last week while walking on Clement Street. Lots of sweets and fresh pastries. Ordered chai tea but unfortunately the cup was only half full and the other half was foam. She didn't quite understand English very well and we decided not to bother with it. Probably wouldn't go back here as there are plenty of other bakeries on Clement street to try out. Place has lots of seating area and its clean and bright.
author: Pravin L.

description:
Love this bakery. Ladies here are nice.
What I get? 

Creamy french (a baguette with a creamy filling inside) sliced and toasted is the way to go.
 Also like the jalapeño bread but that doesn't arrive at the bakery until 10 or 11am. They don't bake in house here...
author: Liz N.

description: They have great breakfast items and salads and sandwiches.  They are also open in the morning, and will make lunch for you at that time to take to work. Nice place to sit and enjoy coffee. The bread is fresh as is everything else. Try it.
author: Susie S.

description: Whenever in the area or after work, I always come in to get the delicious country or whole wheat sour dough bread (depends on how healthy I'm being.) They make pretty good sandwiches-I normally get turkey and love how they add cucumbers. They also make some good pastries like the cheese Danish and Cappuccino cake. I also love thier pizza and pesto pissanos. They are owned by Anderson Bakery I'm sure but with a more French sounding name. Anyway, some of the best tasting sandwhich bread you can buy, although, prices have gone up in recent years.
author: Petra S.

description: I bought 2 plain and I almond croissant . Everyone took a bite and three people threw them in the garbage . Nothing like the bakery around the corner which was closed so we thought being around the corner  would motivate an effort to reproduces similar quality.  But no such luck, tasted like cardboard!!!
author: Paula K.

description:
I would like to write a review since I'm not able to get a hold of corporate. I would rate this place a 1 based on customer service. However I could never bring myself to hurt someone's business, it's just not right. 

First and foremost, I must tell you that this is my favorite place to get a sandwich in Mountain View. The food and pastries are always incredibly delicious. I look forward to coming here  specifically for the food. They have an amazing product! The only thing I dread is walking in and having to wait. There is usually just one person that is tending to clients and she usually is not in sight. It is usually a woman of Indian decent. Not to point out anyone's race as everyone is the same to me... just for the purposes of specificity. 

She never smiles and always looks incredibly put out to take your order. I can't tell you how many countless times I have come in and waited 20 minutes just to be acknowledged and have my order taken. While I am waiting for my order people come in and wait and get frustrated and leave. Not just one person but several people. 

Though they close at five, this woman usually starts putting things away at 3:30. People will come in and see that there are no pastries and walk out. I wish this could be different as I don't want this business to leave. They could have such a booming business if they just spent more time training their employee/s  on customer service.

A few or 2 years back, they had this young gentleman that was incredibly customer service oriented. Very polite and efficient. Where did he go? Or where are the owners, or how can I get a hold of corporate?
author: Hilda G.

description:
Omg. Just had the BBQ chicken sandwich on sour dough. It was SOOOO GOOD. I am in love. Super fast service and the girls working were so sweet. I could eat this sandwich every day and be happy! 
Portions are also big. I was full off of half and took the rest for later.
author: Brenna S.

description: Great service and a nice selection!! With so many amazing bakeries in this city, the competition is fierce---but if you are looking for a nice selection of home-made bread loafs, this is a good option! My fave, the walnut bread---good by itself, perfect for French toast!!
author: Fiorella L.

description: Amazing pastries, cute shop with enough tables to eat inside.  I'm visiting San Fran and unfortunately didn't find this gem until the end of my stay.  Stopping here is a must!
author: Natalie H.

description:
Immaculately clean and very polite staff. They are so sweet and thorough in their sandwich making skills. Huge variety of tasty breads to choose from. All sandos loaded with crisp, fresh veggies. Love this!

If you're craving something sweet I really enjoy they're walnut bread with sweet cream cheese. I like it room temperature but they can warm it up too. 

The condiments are always organized and plentiful. And they clean their dining tables regularly. Super sweet location and superb little sandwiches on fresh bread. And they have free wifi. Great place to study or get some work done.
author: Rosalyn W.

description: I have been coming to this Grain D'Or for some time and it is always good and consistent but today I just had to write a review because the service by your employee Sue is 5 stars. I have always had great service here but this lady takes it to another level. So friendly, thinks ahead, fast on her feet and just so hospitable. So much so that myself and another customer looked at each other and said wow- she is so good. Hope this gets back to her ears and those of the owner.
author: Victoria H.

description: To tell you the truth. I very want to like this place. The two stars is for the older Asian lady that move around faster than the young guy that works there. She is the reason I go back. Don't get me wrong the bake goods are great(1 star) but this woman is awesome. The negative two stars is because of the Asian guy that works there. Twice now that he pisses me off. The first time was when I went in to get a sandwich. Request for a ketchup and he told me that they don't have it. This is even when I went in there like a hundred times and saw a ketchup in their dining room area. I have to go in search for it. Second times is today. I called to order a cake so I won't have to waste my time since I am super tight for time. A Russian lady picked up the phone and after I explained to her. She said they don't except order by phone. Ok???? So I have to do on line or come in...well.. cannot go on line since I am driving. Went in and proceeded to tell the Asian guy that I need a cake with a writing for Birthday. Told me that I should of order on line. That they need a time ahead. Ok??? I told him I tried to call by phone but if they needed time. I can pay for it first and come back after they are done writing on the cake. He shut my idea down by telling me that they don't have a tool to do that. Hmmm.. funny that about two months ago, the Asian lady did it for me. I got tired of this ass provoking anger in me. I just told him forget it. Not sure if he is lazy or can give a shit about his job. I ended going to the one in Japan town and they are so much smaller space but equipped with tools to do what I requested. I asked her if other place are equipped to have the writing tool for cake. She said yes they all does. Lazy little shit! I hate people like him. I won't be going back there no more. Thanks Ass wipe!
author: S F.

description: The cranberry walnut bread here is a must. I get off work an hour early just so I can get to Grain D'Or in time to get bread. Their cookies are ehhhh, had better. But if you go here, get their loafs of bread. The price is fairly cheap in comparison to other bakeries.
author: Ariunaa B.

description: I really want to love this place because it's cute and located next to my favorite farmer's market, but, I'm always disappointed in the pastries. They're too dry for my taste and they lack a real buttery taste and crispness. The coffee is equally ehh to my tastebuds. They do carry a diverse selection of Mighty Leaf teas, which I find are always excellent. Regardless, it's a sweet, little place with very reasonable prices.
author: Megan M.

description: Service is very slow for made to order food. I am currently waiting for food, and people are lined up in front of the counter waiting. Nobody has been served in 20 minutes and people who ordered before us have received their food. Two stars for having a nice aesthetic.
author: Audrey G.

description:
I have found my new addiction - chicken salad sandwich on RAISIN bread. How come I've never had this combo before?! 

Anyways, just tried out Grain D'or for the first time & I was satisfied. 
The food quality is really good, especially their variety of bread. 
My boyfriend got a breakfast sandwich & he enjoyed it. 

They do take a little while to make the food & the sandwiches aren't exactly PACKED, but it was still really good. 
I'll be back to try their desserts or danishes very soon.
author: Sylvia N.

description: We're staying at an AirBnB down the road on Clement St. and decided to stop in before a day of exploring - I grabbed some anpan while my boyfriend had some kind of pastry with walnut and cream cheese. We were both very pleased! Service was quick and friendly and the sitting area is very clean.
author: Shea R.

description: Staff here are really nice! They have organic coffee and great pastries and bread. You can ask to toast and/or slice the pastries and they'll gladly do it for you. I always get the cream cheese walnut sliced, creamy french, cheese breads (all are good to me), and apple raisin whole loaf sliced. Sometimes I get them all at one time to eat for breakfast for the entire week.
author: N N.

description: There's a lady named Sue, and she's the absolute sweetest! She carefully packages everything, and always hand selects each order. She always magically chooses the one I'm eyeing somehow. I love when I see her, she just makes my day. Some people are just amazing, and Sue is a beautiful amazing person!!
author: Thuy M.

description:
This place is so yummy!

I came here with my friend last year just to kill some time and see if the noms were any good.

I bought a slice of the chocolate ganche cake, and man it was good! I definitely need to come back and try the other noms like the bread and such.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
Nice neighborhood bakery that uses Andersen's bread.
serves breakfast sandwiches, soups, pastries, breads, etc.

coffees here are meh...but carb selection is quite big.  friendly people.  
get a window seat and watch people walk by the best street in sf-clement!
author: Linda T.

description: I work near by and grab lunch here at least 3x a week. great service and sandwiches are always fresh and made to order.
author: Cindy C.

description:
My previous 2-star rating was unfair given how much I eat here. I still feel the consistency and stocking issues need a lot of improvement.

Do come here for freshly baked loaves and half-loaves of bread.
Do come here for the signature sandwiches.

Don't come here for the pastries.
Don't come here looking for anything more than a decent sandwich.
author: Sam S.

description: Dry and stale. no flavor just sweet bread to cover up the lack of flavor. I wouldn't recommend this place
author: Nader N.

description: If you're looking for daily fresh croissants, this place is NOT for you. Beside, they taste horrible. They were baked at least the day before and made with some fat, most likely with cheap fat, not with butter. Sad to say, but Safeway croissants are cheaper and taste better than their croissants. It should not be grain d'or but grain beurk
author: Jean-Yves F.

description:
Double agent.

Apparently a part of the Andersen Bakery family. Much goodness here: http://www.yelp.com/user_details_review_search?q=Andersen+bakery&userid=WecuAsHBDZGj7Z6_sJcQAw

This includes a previously discovered and enjoyed $2 double chocolate cookie. Never hurts to make sure it's as good as you remember. And it certainly was.
author: Jason B.

description: The staff is really friendly, they play great music and everything is so yummy!! Dean helped me and is very nice and friendly.
author: Kristianne M.

description:
Walked in here to try the pastries as I'm new in the neighborhood. Bought a ham and cheese croissant, almond croissant, and plain croissant to take home. All three were terrible. Dry, stale, unimaginative. A plain croissant shouldn't be that hard to get if you're a bakery, but we found ourselves peeling off dry outer layers and leaving bits of pastry unfinished... not usually a problem!

Also, what's up with the SF health tax for a purchase of pastries to go? Never seen this anywhere else. Definitely not enticed to come back here and try again.
author: Nika T.

description: The place is immaculate, the girls who work there are beyond nice, and the chicken salad sandwiches on raisin bread....nom, nom, nom. The crossaints are also top notch. 5 stars!
author: Chelsey G.

description: it's fine but it's not great. i came here because the line at Blue Danube was too long, and now i'm somewhat regretting my impatience. ordered a "vegetarian feast" sandwich on a baguette and an iced latte. i have nothing terrible to say... just wasn't impressed.
author: Ronny K.

description:
This place is very hit & miss. 

Things I love:
Raisin Bread (very generous with the raisins)
Apple Pie (it's more of a fritter than pie but still yummy)
Hot Cross Buns (so sad these are seasonal for Easter only)
Pain de Campagne bread (light & airy)
Ciabatta Bread (perfect and cheaper than the grocery store stuff)

Things that are gross:
All their pastries (very bland)
Coffee (tastes like water)

Their poundcakes are good but very overpriced.

The storefront is very nice. A comfortable place to sit. But they mop about 30 minutes before closing and it makes the floor like an oil slick. When I was 6 months pregnant I had a bad fall here because of it and they agreed to not mop the entire restaurant while they are open. It seems like no one informed the current manager who has them mopping with customers again. i just hope no one gets hurt or goes through the pain and hassle I went through my last 3 months of pregnancy from the bruising of the fall, which thankfully was not worse and didn't hurt my baby.
author: Venus S.

description:
I saw this place and immediately thought "independent cute bread shop." Not quite--it's just a "boutique" arm of Andersen with pretty much the same quality bread. $3.50 for a small loaf of ciabatta felt too expensive for me, but not painfully so.

The people who work here are super helpful, and if the environment is a bit cliche there's nothing necessarily wrong with that
author: Paul C.

description: Annoying because service was so good here before. Today, when my sandwich was ready (which took longer than usual) the person called out my sandwich from the opposite end of the restaurant and there were people standing between us so I didn't want to shout through the people and I didn't want to leave my stuff at my table unattended nor gather up my stuff and lose my table (tables were all taken and people were in line). This happened today, Sunday, at 2:15pm. Why did the girl take two people their sandwiches but not take me mine? Ugh I waited for her to try again but eventually I was forced to go get it myself. It used to be much better.
author: Jason B.

description:
Fresh pastries, big open space in front, relaxed feeling. 

Today, had a 'Farmers Chicken Salad Sandwich' on Cabata bread was good - don't forget to ask them to toast the bread. Perfect sandwich, thought it was going to be alot of mayo - NOT. That's a good thing. Will definitely come back...

Thanks for being in the richmond dist.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Fresh bread is the only selling point for this place - the sandwiches are thin and bland. They look and feel no different than if you just threw some cold-cuts together in your own home (and you'd pay half as much to do it in your own home) 
Many other superior sandwich places nearby.
author: Double T.

description: Clean and cheerily lit, Grain d'Or is calm, quiet and spacious, and not overcrowded like many bakeries. They serve a delicious California BLT (I've had this twice now), and I can't wait to try the pastries. They look perfect!
author: Jennifer M.

description:
I come here for the cream Brulee. What I don't understand is a tip jar on the counter
AND a charge for the San Francisco health care. With minimum wage what it is, you
would think Anderson bakery chain would just add the  health care into the prices and
take away the tip jar. If other business follows their practices I expect to see a tip jar
for the cashier at Safeway.  And after all this I still had to clean my own table when
I sat down and when I left. All this takes away from wanting to come here.
author: Peter F.

description: Came across this place when out on a recent walk. Had fresh made sandwiches for lunch -- just lovely. Made to order, fresh ingredients and quickly prepared. Bought bread and French pastries to take away. Lovely treat. Store is roomy, very clean and the service is excellent. Clean restrooms and seems like a popular neighbourhood store. Highly recommend.
author: Tanya F.

description: I love this place. I'm a student on budget who needs an easy access to wifi, good lighting, and reliable space to work.  There is only one outlet spot in the cafe, unfortunately, but tons of seating area. They accept debit/credit card, which is super convenient compared to most coffee shops on clement that only accept cash. Quality of coffee is actually not super wow factor, unfortunately. But reasonable for the low price:p. They are bakery, therefore their fresh sandwiches are delicious!! I buy sliced English wheat bread for the house. also love having their minestrone and clam chowder soup!  Customer service here always always impress me, and you will feel very appreciated and valued as a customer. Very family friendly and you will see people of a wide age range. Awesome place in the neighborhood!
author: Hanna B.

description:
I've never been to Europe but I'd imagine this is what a cute little European cafe/ bakery would be like. They definitely focus on breads here, no pink cupcakes or colorful macaroons here.

 Nice little quiet place with big tables to spread out, read the paper or catch up with some friends. I loved how spacious this place was, light came through the big windows facing Clement street even on a gray rainy day. I was actually surprised that they did not put more tables in this place since there was plenty of space for more seating. The employees were very sweet and friendly. 

I got the Minestrone soup - hearty thick veggie soup, not too salty! Served with generous side of fresh, soft bread. I also ordered the "pizzas" - bread topped with marinara sauce and cheese. Perfect pairing! My friend got the pesto bread also very delicious. 

There is not way you can resist grabbing some baked goods to take home and share (or not!!). The braided raisin bread with icing is AMAZING. It magically disappeared while I was driving home......
author: Eva H.

description:
Yum. 

Pastries here are also awesome. Strawberry danish, creamy french, and cheese breads. All great for breakfast. They also have a small variety of cakes, fruit tarts and even creme brule! A loaf of premium white bread is $3.50 and is OH SO SOFT. Almost like a bag of marshmallows in a big...but flat...with crusts....and tastes like bread.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
Walking distance from my work which is a big plus.

I've only tried the chicken salad sandwich on sourdough bread here. I love it. It's very delicious and filling. They have so many good looking pastries/desserts that I have yet to try. Must definitely come back and try them all.
author: Justine O.

description:
Grain D'or is the Richmond district branch of the Japanese bakery chain, Andersen Bakery, which prides itself in creating breads and pastry of "European taste and quality."

Translation: Since it's a Japanese version of Euro carb treats, everything for sale will be less sweet, less fatty and less salty (i.e. "bland" for some folks, but just right if you're into Japanese and Asian style tastes).

I just had a pumpkin pie slice I got for $1.50 -- not sure if that's the regular price or if it was a special b/c it was the day before Thanksgiving.

The pumpkin pie filling was not cloyingly sweet and had a clear gelatin layer on top.  The crust was golden and flaky.

I also got some Japanese style red bean paste buns called "Anpan" that Grain D'or/Andersen Bakery is known for as gifts for Japanese friends.

I usually get things to go, but I'm thinking about coming back to just sit and chill out with a cup of tea and pastry.  The bakery is airy, clean-looking with wooden floors and has a unisex-bathroom (a plus when other bakeries on Clement don't have a bathroom).

Another plus -- they take credit cards with no minimum.
author: Bodhi D.

description: This is my very favorite bakery in San Francisco! Finally I found some decent bread in this city, hooray. Multigrain bread, bread with raisons or walnuts and cranberries. These fresh breads are only a little more pricey than the packaged breads you can find everywhere and simply delicious. Worth jumping on the bus every weekend to stock up for the week. Tip: buy this bread and you'll impress your European friends at brunch for sure!
author: Patricia D.

description: Love, love, love the California BLT. Super nice people, clean place, and yummy desserts!
author: Michelle A.

description:
We were right around the corner shopping at Kisha's. While we waited for some things to be fixed, we stopped by for some coffee and morning pastries. 

The cafe au lait is nice. It wasn't anything special, but it was good and strong. 

The cream puffs are delish. The cream fillng is light and flavorful. We also got a strawberry danish like thing along with a croissant. We cut everything into little pieces and split it 3 ways so everyone would have a taste. 

The layout and space are great. Tons of room to spread out. The service was also nice and she brought us extra napkins, trays, and sugar for the drinks.
author: Debby L.

description: little hidden gem, clean, decent bread servings, samples available, friendly staff free wifi, nice mellow jazz playing in the background,  good atmosphere for slow pace, quiet ambience.
author: Ron P.

description:
I love their creme brulee. 

A very quiet, spacious place. This place would be good for studying.
author: Mandy D.

description: Don't go if you're planning to sit in the bakery because the shop itself is ALWAYS 110 degrees!! The bread and pastries are good but Jesus is it hot inside. No air circulation and big windows allowing the sun to create the perfect sauna inside. It's been there for over 5years now, when are they going to install a A/C?
author: k k.

description: Great bread friendly service.  Love the tuna and BLT sandwiches.  This is my go-to spot for lunch in the Richmond
author: Justin H.

description:
Okay, I came here alot when I was in middle school but that was then. It's a place filled with breads and pastries. So if you're a carb lover there you go. Even though it's a bakery I don't think they make their own stuff. Like some of their cakes actually comes from Anderson bakery. So it's  not a bakery just a place that sells the stuff. 

  Anyways my vivid memory was that there was a day where I was there with a friend and the one talking to us was the head woman and she was chatting to us. And  she says " Oh it's so nice you are taking your mother here." And it turned out she was referring to me.  I'm like "Excuse me?! Do I look like her mother? I'm freakin 14!" So she needs to get her eyes checked. Because that pissed me off. She is not a young thing either she was like in her 50s. I'm so turned off by that place I never went in there again.
author: Julie Z.

description:
Carbs!!!

Yes, it's a chain.  Yes, it's kind of at the end or beginning of the hubub that is Clement street, but I like it!

Cheap- most breads/pastries run you about $2-$5 bucks.  

MUST: cheese roll, garlic cheese, pesto... dear god, all the bread items are just wonderful!

Parking:  Not fun.
author: Christine K.

description: Great cheap sandwiches for lunch! Portions are big, Quick Service and the workers can remember your order.  Will be coming back.
author: Brian C.

description: The pastries are always fresh. I usually will get the Creamy French, or the Cheese Danish and No, I do not share! I've tried the the Tuna Sandwich and Chicken Cesar Salad and those were also always fresh and tasty. The ladies here are always nice and courteous. Most of the time when I'm here it's early in the morning so it's always quiet. Very clean too.
author: C D.

description:
The first thing i noticed upon entering Grain d'Or was the magnificent display of bakery art. However, once I got past the tinsel and glitter, I experienced nothing but more tinsel and glitter. I ordered a twisty thing that supposedly included saffron, but in the end tasted liike the bland, mass produced danishes that are routinely provided in the exhibiting areas of conferences i attend during the course of the medical research I conduct. My wife was not ovely impressed with her ham and cheese croissant, but far be it from me to usurp her own opportunity to yelp this joint; she often overrates (at least in my opinion) places that I (in her opinion) underrate, to balance things overall in the overall cosmic allness of everything.

Concerning the coffee, I thought she stated it tasted like someone had "run a concubine through it" -- at least that is what I heard, being somewhat hard of hearing. She corrected this later on, and stipulated that what she had actually said was that her father would have said the coffee tasted like someone had "run a coffee bean through it." Concubine, coffee bean, what difference does it make? I will not be seen in Grain D'Or again, because food art is to be seen, not eaten. As for the glowing reviews the others herein have provided, I can only conclude that food art is in the eyes of the beholder, and some people's eyes are dumber than their stomachs.
author: Robert C.

description:
I can't believe I haven't written a review for Grain D'Or yet! Shame on me! 

I lived in the area but sadly never bothered to come in here until when my bf's mom came to visit and bought some bread and pastries from here for us. That was the day I fell in love with this place! 

Here are my must haves:
1) Creamy French Roll ($2.25)
2) Cheese Danish Pastry ($3.00)
3) Raspberry Cream Cheese ($2.25)

Occasionally I get the Strawberry Pastry ($2.25) and today I decided to get the Apple Pie ($2.10) for breakfast tomorrow. 

The Creamy French Roll is a hit or miss depending on what time you go in... obviously the later you go, chances are they may be sold out. I would suggest to eat these within a day or so. The raspberry cream cheese has a hint of almond abstract in it. 

I have yet to try their sandwiches but next time I come I will try their pesto or jalapeno bread ($3.50). I have admit though, that the price of these breads and pastry is not cheap, but let me reassure you that they are damn good. 

The only little thing that irks me when I come is that you tell them what you want and they get them one by one and after the bag one of them they go to the register to ring it up, go back to get whatever else you want, ring it up until you have all that you want. It would make more sense to me if they just bagged everything and then ring it up at once. I'm not sure if it's because they are afraid they will forget what you buying or what, but there has to be a better way of doing it.
author: Eugenia G.

description: Do NOT eat the chicken Cesar salad. Warm lettuce and disgusting, smelly, microwaved chicken that was spongy and probably rotten. Haven't eaten anything else there but if they make a salad THAT gross, I wouldn't eat anything else from this place.
author: Basil C.

description:
I was running on empty (fueled by Red Bull) and beginning to feel naseous. I went to cellular biology, got called in to work at my other job, and was about to start dinner shift at my other job. I needed to eat SOMETHING before I passed out.
Quick! What to eat on Clement that's quick!? Fast! Hurry!
Park Life? Wait no, Susy don't go in there - you'll end up buying yourself cute tshirts. NEED SUSTENANCE NOW!

So I spent $2.75 on pesto bread. 

It's not mind blowing like good sex or anything like that. 
Just mediocre...

Er, it's really clean inside. And that's all i've got to say about that.
author: Susy C.

description:
First of all, I love that this place opens early. For anyone who has ever tried parking on Clement, you know that early is pretty much the ONLY way you'll find a space. I love stopping by a little after 8 AM on my way to work... the bonus being that the meters aren't running yet.

Their pastries are delicious and not too sweet, which is rare gem in these days of over-sugared over-glazed over-frosted everything. Their walnut cream cheese pastry is lovely: almost like having a bagel with cream cheese but just slightly sweeter. I also highly recommend their savory breads: the pesto is one of my favorites. I have yet to try their regular loaves but they look great. 

I also haven't tried the coffee or the sandwiches: I usually stop at the Blue Danube for the caffeine fix and then walk over here, and at 8 AM I'm not thinking about sandwiches yet. But I'm sure I'll try them both at some point.

The only negative? The fixation on keeping the door open, even at 8 AM on a winter day. I'm guessing it's probably hot back there in the kitchen, but for us poor souls buying our goods, it's just downright cold.
author: Alison Y.

description:
I was so happy to discover this place walking distance from my front door. By far the best bread I have found in the city (MUCH better than anything you find in the supermarket).  Staff are always friendly and polite. I love the free tasters and the fact that this place is spacious and quiet.  
Their almond croissant is wonderful, soft and flakey and just sweet enough. They even sell British style hot-cross buns!  Their fresh sandwiches are also pretty good.
author: Izzy A.

description: Love this place! Their Cesar salads and CA BLT are the best! I get one of those options almost weekly for lunch! Their bread is great too! I would give 5 stars, but in terms of a bakery they should have more sweets.  The staff is very friendly and the place is spotless! Very bright and clean!
author: Natalia H.

description: Whether its for a baguette, a sandwich, or sliced loaf of their jalapeno bread, I can't help but love this place. Super simple and sterile on the inside with very nice people behind the counter, my experience is always fantastic here. Parking can get tough, but its worth it.
author: Jen M.

description:
A+ for cleanliness. In a city where we get used to the dirt, you guys are keeping up appearance -- can't be easy. I also love the classical music.

Unlike nearly every other place in San Francisco, the workers here are thorough and POLITE. I mean, genuinely polite, and it's not because they are speaking in a language that I don't happen to speak; I've never even accidently caught them making tmi personal remarks at each other or acting grossly unprofessional and thinking they're "cool" for it. No, they are actually talking at a moderate volume about something other than getting trashed or making fun of the last person who came in. The men and women here have been well trained and happen to be attractive to boot -- not that they act full of themselves because of it. Seriously, that alone is a minor miracle. It's probably not fun to wear the cute uniforms, but you all do it well if that's any consolation.

Enough about the people, on to the food. I regularly stop here for a fresh sandwich -- their chicken salad is a little sweet for me, but now you can custom order it on non-raisin bread. It's also nice to get a selection of veggies.

Their espresso is always well prepared. I've not been cheated or gotten something barely drinkable -- it's FRESH, the machine is CLEAN. Just make sure to ask for a small cup or you may get an difficult to drink overflowing shot cup! The juice selection is always cold and well stocked (Naked or Odwalla, plus non-smoothie varities). I tend to also like this with a sandwich. They have chips. They also have tasty BAGEL chips in big bags.

It's true, their pastries are not the best (though fresh). However, they are by far not the worst either. C'mon, most coffee shops are selling Costco goods. And I'd say their BREAD is excellent. As a child I could hardly get enough of the round ones with melted cheese inside (which one may ask to be sliced). Buy any loaf, take it home. Make up your own mind. Bread freezes and toasts, it's a simple luxury in a tired day.

Often they have samples out, a terrific way to find a new flavor.

Our family is particularly fond of things done with sesame seeds -- surprisingly tasty on a loaf. We like the whole grains too. We also like the red bean baked goods and bread. ORDER THEM! :D

Their pastries are not overly sweet -- true to EUROPEAN standards. My family prefers this as well. However, if you do like sweet, the raspberry cream is probably for you. Their blueberry or strawberry danish are excellent -- puff of crisp pastry, touch of real fruit, hidden layer of modest custard and a drizzle of icing. Strawberry shortcake is fun, and one day they were out of slices and the young woman thought nothing of offering to cut up the last cake to fill the order. So, I bought more than one slice and nicely tipped.

My only quibble -- I need to use a bathroom.
author: Ziggy J.

description:
Chicken salad sandwich was ordered.

This spot is really clean and spacious.  A nice choice of food and the price is good.

The chicken salad sandwich I had was delicious.
author: Roger A.

description:
This is one of the Andersen Bakery's chain (http://www.andersenbakery.com), although I don't understand why they keep using two bands.  I'm not sure exactly the breakdown of the financial ownership of Andersen Bakery USA, but Andersen Group in Japan helped finance Diamond Foods to open their first U.S. store 'Grain D'Or' in San Mateo in 1981.  Since then, Diamond Foods name was changed to Andersen Bakery.  So, how tight is the link between Andersen Group in Japan (http://www.andersen-ap.co.jp/) with Andersen USA?  As a consumer, I don't' really care about the mechanics of the investments, but rather about the product, which in my mind is quite different than the great offerings at Stores in Japan.  Also, I don't see why they seem to hide the Japanese angle to this store.  Without the Japanese stuff, this bakery is nothing special.  There are so many better bakeries in the area like Boulangerie Bay Bread (http://www.yelp.com/biz/tQE4SPlX9ZlFSbF4JPU4pg) and Tartine Bakery (http://www.yelp.com/biz/ri7UUYmx21AgSpRsf4-9QA).  I wish Andersen would start becoming a bit more Japanese like Clover Bakery in San Jose (http://www.yelp.com/biz/NQ0KQoCTdkXICx36Z0t_lA).

I used to love going to Andersen in Japan, I mean twice a day!!!  Give me my Curry filled bread!!!
author: トモ T.

description:
This is a good place to fuel quickly if you're passing by (we went there before Love Fest!). The serving sizes are perfectly fulfilling, imo.

My fav. is the veggie feast on the 9-grain bread stuffed w/ avocados, sprouts, and the like....mmm...The eggplant mozzarella is enticing as well.

The pastries are pretty good as well, and I LOVE the raspberry and cream cheese pastry, and the chocolate fudge brownies. 

Like others have said, friendly staff--they work well together to get your food to you quickly. I'd return if I'm in the area.
author: Stefanie H.

description:
I love long hard things with creaminess oozing out of them... like the creamy French bread at Grain d'Or!  (yeah get yer mind outta the gutter!)

FOOD:  I'm a carb wh*re.  I admit it.  Dr. Atkins would consume carbs just by sharing the air I breathe.  Anywho, the creamy french is always a winner here.  In fact it's the only French I like (just kidding keep your berets on!)  But also dependably good are their almond croissants, cupcakes (it's nice because it's the first bakery cupcake I've had that's not DROWNING in frosting!) and their milk french (little pastries filled with condensed milk).  Wanted to also try their savory breads since I'm a savory kinda girl while I was here... for next time!

AMBIENCE: Kind of out of place for the neighborhood, methinks.  A bit too yuppy-ish for the Chinese grandmas that haunt Clement street with their overstuffed shopping bags.  But the location is clean, it's easy to find and less people going in means they'll always have what I want available!

PRICES: Not bad at all.  I got a creamy french, 4 milk french pastries, 4 cupcakes and 2 large croissants for $19 even.   Not bad I'd say!

PARKING: Is a huge b*tch on Clement street.  Bus or walk here if you can.  Otherwise be prepared to circle around hundreds of Moms who can't park their minivans straight as you muddle through SF's unofficial second Chinatown.
author: Catherine C.

description: Really just your run-of-the-mill chain bakery. Nothing more to say other than their bread tastes fine, and they sell sandwiches along with a cheaper array of baked goods to go with your rather large order of freshly baked bread. I had a turkey-and-swiss from them, and I also sampled some cinnamon bread and sugared bread. Nothing to write home about; very similar to Boudin.
author: Danny C.

description: The pastries here are pretty scrumptious! Came here for an early breakfast and shared a few different pastries with my cousin and sister. The winner being their specialty garlic and cheese bread! Yummm...also really enjoyed the raspberry strip pastry thing. I forgot what it's called but it's filled with raspberry and cream cheese and my cousin made me eat the strip in a straight line to enjoy all of the fillings. Mocha was pretty good too.
author: Mymy N.

description:
Meh, I wasn't impressed. I am a big fan of fresh baked bread. And yeah, this has fresh baked bread, but it is nothing that I couldn't also get at the super market. I bought the sour dough and the whole grain wheat. The sourdough tastes exactly like San Luis Sourdough, which I really like, but I can buy at any supermarket. The wheat bread was good, lots of grains and oat mixed in. But the crust is kinda hard and chewy. 
Finally, I didn't really like the service. The gentleman who was helping me was very soft spoken and I couldn't understand a word he was saying. Even thought the place was basically empty and there wasn't a whole lot of other noise. I got the impression that he didn't really want to be there.
author: Krystal W.

description: My roommate recently brought home quite possibly THE GREATEST loaf of freshly-baked French bread that I have ever had in my entire gosh-darn life. And to that I say: thank you, Grain D'Or. Thank you.
author: Eva J.

description:
Caesar salad -= excellent
Veg soup = very good
All breads = outstanding
Eclair -- yum!
author: Arthur C.

description:
I am a carb FIEND. CARBS ARE MY CRACK, plain and simple.

There is no question, once I spent two weeks of my life without carbs because the South Beach Diet told me I couldn't.

I WILL NEVER PULL THAT CRAP EVER AGAIN. Sustaining from carbs that long has just made me love them even more.

I love that I live just a few blocks from this bakery. It gives me what I need, savory carbs: pesto bread, international cheese bread, bread, bread and more bread. I also live off of their creamy french rolls and cheese danishes. You might think its blasphemous of me to compare Porto's FAMOUS Cheese Rolls to a Grain D'Or Cheese Danish, and thats ok--go ahead and throw stones at me, but unfortunately Portos is no where near the Bay and I gotta get my fix where I can!

Ohh and P.S. the staff is ALWAYS friendly and super accommodating.
author: kate r.

description:
Brain D'ead
Bad B'read
Wasted S'pace
Stay A'way
author: Brian J.

description:
I enjoy going to the one in Serramonte better. Although if I get lazy to drive all the way over there, I come here. 

The ladies behind the counter is the sweetest people ever. They always ask how my day is and makes sure I'm helped when I'm ready. I always go for the pesto cheese bread, international cheese bread, and garlic cheese bread. (Yes all cheese breads because I do LOVE cheese!) They're pretty cheap too, at around $2.50 each and it's a pretty big order of bread. If it's not fresh, ask them to warm it for you, (way better when it's warm and the cheese is melted and gooey!) and slice it so you can munch while you explore Clement st. 

Although I have tried their strawberry shortcake, I didn't like it. It was dry and crumby.. I hate dry and crumby cakes!
author: Juliane N.

description: Nice quiet place to have a cup of coffee with my sister and have some dessert.  Love the "creamy French" which is a custard filled mini baguette -sounds little weird but you have the taste of a mildly yeasty French bread (with a thin crust) and a silky vanilla custard. The artisan breads are wonderful and fresh and sandwiches are made to order. Stop by almost every Saturday. Staff is friendly and courteous.
author: Lilly B.

description:
How did we not notice this bakery and we had eaten at establishments close by. Perhaps they changed their store front? Oh well, we came in and peruse their goods but found them to be pricey so we ended up just getting a piece of the raisin bread, $1.75. It was topped with sesame, I liked the texture and it had sufficient raisins with every bite but bf thought it was overpriced considering the bakeries down several blocks are a lot cheaper and tasty as well. The baked goods looked ok but nothing that screamed for attention.

The place looks white and artsy and perhaps their cakes are delicious but maybe we'll venture back....
author: Yan M.

description:
Go early in the morning.

Walnut cream cheese danish.

Almond Croissant.

Scones
Muffins

mini Creme Brulee

mini Cheesecakes

Poundcake
Banana Poundcake.

They serve coffee, too.  And they open EARLY.  My favorite Sunday morning snacks.
author: Lauren R.

description:
No character.  No charm.  And nothing to stand out as a neighborhood bakery. 

The place is fine if you just want to swing by to pick up dinner dough, baguette, or croissant, but the sterile look just isn't conducive to hanging out with a friend for coffee or pastry... esp. there is Blue Danube nearby.  Or the new Martha & Bro. Coffee Company that just opened a block away...
author: Shirley F.

description:
The best place I know of for any pastry with cream cheese filling: danishes and walnut bun with cream cheese filling.  

I like the loaf of cinnamon bread, too.  It's around $4.  Good price for bread with a twist.  

I like the thick, gooey cream cheese-filled pastries here.
author: Mrs F.

description:
I think Nate W. is wrong when he gives this place only 3 stars because its too sterile. I don't know where he bakes his loaves because the last thing I want in my bread is a hair, a dust bunny, or any other foreign object.  
The bread here is whispy soft whole grain goodness. The French Cream/ Cream French things are amazing. Thanks to other yelpers for introducing me to those!
author: Danielly A.

description:
Interesting patries, nothing to jump all over about, though.  

Clean bakery, nice staff.  EZ parking when you need something at 6AM.
author: Dong T.

description:
What a waste of space.

Large clean space with 3 different kinds of bread.  And that's it.  


Not even a good bakery smell.

Bummer.
author: Alison R.

description:
Its pretty nice living so close to a bakery.  I cook a lot and most of the time the bf  will want some bread with dinner.  We've frequented this place enough to be recognized by the sweet lady who runs/owns the place.  She's always so nice and inviting that its hard not to go in when you pass by.  
They have a nice selection of breads from baguettes to boules to cranberry walnut bread.  They also have an assortment of croissants, breakfast pastries, and some sort of cheese filled bread that I absolutely love.  Its also an immaculate establishment! So clean you can probably eat off the floors.
author: Maria B.

description:
I used to work near the Grain D'Or on Market St and was ecstatic to find a branch on Clement near my apartment. They offer the same delicious cheese breads I love, but with a more spacious and relaxing atmosphere than the downtown branch. As previous reviews have noted, the ladies that work there are super nice and accommodating. 

My favorites are the international cheese bread, pesto cheese bread, and cheddar cheese roll. I always get the bread sliced because it is easier to eat and share. They will also heat up your cheese bread and it is quite tasty this way. 

They offer specialty coffee drinks but they aren't very good. Go for the fresh juices or save some cash with drip coffee. 

This has become my favorite hang over salvation stop on Saturday and Sunday morning/afternoons. Sadly they close at 6 pm weekdays so I cannot stop in after work.
author: Kristen C.

description: Most of the time the breads are decent, but sometimes they'd give you disgusting, hard-as-a-rock, stale breads. UGH. Thanks for picking the worst bread on the shelf for me today. It's partly my fault since I should have told them to switch... But seriously, did you really have to give me THE stale one when there are other 2 fresh breads on the same shelf left!??
author: Bobo V.

description: I decided to stop by Georgio's Pizzeria up the corner to pick up a pizza and while I was waiting for it, I ventured across the street to Grain D'Or.  Not a good place to stop by after work. The shelves were practically barren.  Do they sell out their items so quickly or just control their inventory by making less?  I picked up 2 croissants and had forgotten that last year I reviewed that that Jr. Yelpers complained they were too dry and not buttery enough.  That's what you get for not re-reading your own review.  Yelping is like having a food diary stored into the world of the internet, use it wisely.
author: Ry T.

description: I absolutely love buying fresh baked bread from this place. My favorites are the Whole Grain and the French Sourdough. They also have the best made to order sandwiches. The turkey, tomato, mozzarella sandwich is to die for! They originally gave it to me as a free sample and now I'm hooked. The pastries are great... croissants, eclairs, cream bread.... all good! and the service is very friendly and attentive.
author: Shannon A.

description:
I love Grain D'or if not just for the sweet lady who runs the place. The coffee was fine although I'm not sure they know what an au'lait is. The only things I ever get are the apple pie pocket (butter crossaint with apple pie filling... seriously, how can you ever go wrong with apple pie filling?) and the sour cheery danish (I am a bastard and usually just eat the middle part because duh, that's the best part). 

Sterile = Clean. In this neighborhood, it's a blessing to see a place as clean as that (I am not hating on dirt, you hippies, just rats!).

It's just a good place to stop by if I need a quick breakfast thingy and like I said, they're always all smiles! :D
author: Salina Z.

description:
I really needed a loaf of bread, and I was headed to Park Life next door, so I thought, "Why not splurge on some fancy bread?"

Eh. Milton's bread from TJ's is better, and I'd rather hang out at TJ's anyway. I agree completely with the Yelper who said this place is like an airport concession stand. It also reminded me of some place you'd see in a mega-mall in Asia. It had a weird feeling to it, which was only made more weird by the fact that there were four cops hanging around drinking lattes.

When I got home and tried the bread, I wasn't amazed. The crust was hard to chew, and the slices were small.

No thanks.
author: Vandana M.

description:
Summary based on 1 Sunday visit:
--pretty standard coffee house fare
--friendly service
--free wifi (though the current Yelp summary says No)
--parking terrible
author: Rich H.

description:
Past by this place and i asked myself why i've never tried it before.  I went in and saw their strawberry shortcake and I know I just had to try it.  It was not disappointing at all.  Most surprisingly was that it wasn't that sweet and I was able to finish the entire thing.  We also tried the chocolate eclair and that was just all right for me.  

What this bakery lacks is really that "pow" feeling when you taste their stuff.  I guess that's what a chain is all about.  Being solid.
author: AhLin C.

description:
Small, clean bakery with fantastic service.  I have tried a lot of things here, including the apple raisin bread, strawberry shortcake, palmier, garlic cheese bread, apple pie, and last (but certainly NOT least) the almond croissant.  
The almond croissant is amazing... It tastes exactly like Jergen's original lotion smells!  I really like the apple pie as well.. the apples are fresh and it's perfectly cinnamon-y.  

One of the best things about this place is the fact that if I'm super hungry and can't decide what to eat, I can pick up a couple things here, plus a drink (they have Snapple and other cold drinks by the register) for under $10.  Whenever I go anywhere else to eat it seems like my total is always over $15.

Try the almond croissant or apple pie - they are awesome!
author: Stacy S.

description:
It's a good bakery. My personal favs are:
- pisano either tomato or pesto (a sandwich sized roll baked with either of those ingredients)
- casse croute, it's a bread baked with a little more milk making it lighter.
- butter french. Same thing as the casse croute but with butter brushed on the outside.
- the cakes, all of them.
- the sandwiches, too.

The one thing that was a let down was the baguette. The crust was not right and tasted burnt.
author: cyndi L.

description:
This place is quiet, clean, and not particularly crowded. Lovely pastries, and nice service.  The employee ringing you up might not know alot of English, but they're very polite.  There seems to be alot of ordering to go here, so there never seems to be an issue getting a table here.

On our last visit, my father-in-law ordered their pizza type pastry, and went back for seconds. I took that as a high compliment for this place, as he's from Spain, and loves his bread, so it needs to be done properly.

I guess I can understand some of the "bad" reviews for atmosphere, but I think this place is nice when you want to mix it up for a chanbe of pace.
author: Kathleen P.

description:
Yummy in my tummy jalapeno-cheese french roll!  The staff is always very welcoming and friendly.  They also have great sourdough bread.


Very clean :)
author: Tammy L.

description: This place is amazing. The employees are extremely kind and the pastries are to die for. Their bread is always fresh and there is a lot of variety. My boyfriend loves the saffron twist and I think the chocolate croissant is great. If you are ever on clement be sure to go here, and grab some coffee. They just remodeled and it has a very calm atmosphere too!
author: Hannah H.

description:
This is THE place to get pastries and sweets if you are visiting a friend and want to bring something. They have a great selection of choices in terms of pastries. Everything from cream cheese bread to strawberry danishes to cream puffs. Everything is light and sweet, perfect for an afternoon high tea event. 

They wrap everything up nicely and I've always wanted to just bring my laptop and have lunch there by myself. Clean, brights, and relaxing.
author: Annie C.

description:
Altho its a bit pricey for some items, I absolutely LOVE their Jalapeno & Cheese bread/roll/whatever.  Their other rolls are good too but this is the main reason why I go.  The owner and staff are always friendly.

Their other items are good too.
author: Gilbert C.

description: I just left there. I ordered a Reg Chicken Cesar salad. OMG, and not in the good way. That thing was drrryyyyyy! I mean, they only gave me one small cup of dressing and smothered the salad with power parmesan  cheese and parsley. I also had a chocolate eclair and that was not all that great either. Total bummer. I will go back again and give them another try. They had a strawberry pastry that looked pretty good. Hopefully next time will be better. But I will never, ever get another Chicken Cesar from them, no way.
author: Sabs S.

description:
great place to meet ppl.  spacious, clean and bright!  staff is usually generous and polite.  pastry is decent.  hard to compete with the variety from the chinese bakeries nearby, but if you want to sit down, chat w your friends, or read a book and just chill out (without the pretentiousness of the Danube), this is the place.

one star dinged until they PUT IN WI-FI.  maybe that's that's why i'm almost always able to find a table there...
author: D M.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE.

The bread is phenomenal - soft, fresh, fragrant... just magnificent.  The chicken sandwich with avacado, lemon, and basil is amazing.  
The chocolate cake (ganache outside, chocoloate mousse cake inside) is to die for... if its my birthday, buy me this cake.
author: Mary S.

description: Their bread is very fresh. Worth the trip alone. Selection is slim, but sandwiches are great. Wish they had more to chose from. A little pricey but worth it
author: Jeff V.

description: I love this place.When ever I'm feeling a little low, I'll stop by at Grain D'or for a cup of coffe and walnut, cream cheese Danish. It's a real pick me upper. I also love the variety fresh baked bread  that you can have sliced if you so desire . I do so desire. Yummy.
author: Amy F.

description: The artisan sea salt round: intense, serious, flavorful, super bread. Heaven! Half was gone in the few blocks back to the office. And silly as it seems, he did a sesame bagel really well: toasted crunchy and perfect. It's close to work so that's not a good thing. And I wonder if he knows he's ever so cute?
author: Richard A.

description:
Dear Manager:

1. Please tell your new employees not to touch food with their bare hands after rubbing on their red runny noses, and oily faces, and makeup. It's filthy. I've seen it several times now.  They used to use gloves, I believe.

2. Pre-sliced bread steaming in plastic wrap all day long is what you can get at Safeway. You used to have the bare minimum number of loaves packaged because  you understood aesthetics sell in bakeries (i.e., keep the bread out), and you understood that packaged bread products steam in plastic. What's going on?

After coming here for several years, I am not impressed with what's happening at our neighborhood Fakery.
author: Josh H.

description:
Nice loaves ... favorites include the apple raisin bread and the maple wheat.  Other basic sourdough, "country" bread, etc. is good.

Staff is friendly and shop is clean.
author: Broucek J.

description: The ladies behind the counter are so sweet that I fear getting a toothache from just looking at them. The jalepeno roll is super tasty and I tend to finish it in two bites on my walk to the car and am always tempted to go back for another. Good thing my fear of looking like an even bigger dork refrains me from returning right then.
author: Nathalie L.

description: Nice bakery with good staff. I came in one Saturday morning looking for some breakfast pastries. There was no line, so I got to pick and choose and pay all within a couple of minutes. Nice staff, plenty of space between tables, very roomy. The croissant was okay, the strawberry pasty was yummy. I'd come back to try their other stuff.
author: Apple P.

description: Just stopped in because had a craving for something light and wanted to check out the Beige version of a hellokittyKATZenbrot place for the Richmond. It was okay, but it made me wonder how they will do in this location. Oh well. Wish them luck and the best of devoted customers.
author: miriam b.

description: Cute little bakery.  The one thing that I tried on a whim that I totally love is the jalapeno cheese bread.  It's fantastic when it's fresh, and awesome reheated in a toaster oven.  The service is friendly, the coffee also works.  I would totally come back here more often, if it weren't for the parking.  It's takes a while to find a space around here.
author: Tony L.

description: The bread is like Boudin but the staff is so nice that I pick up my sourdough here on the way home.  The really hire genuine people there....
author: Nikki W.

description:
one of the andersen / grain d'or bakeries scattered all over the bay area. 
same bad coffee. ok baked goods.
author: Bennet A.

description: Les baguettes et al are tres francois and smell wonderful in the crisp morning air. I get goosebumps just thinking about all of their delicious baked goodies, and each piece is soo BIG!
author: Sunny T.

description:
two words:  CREAMY FRENCH.  

every other dessert i've had here has also been pretty delicious.
author: asia c.

description: I walked down to this bakery to grab lunch the other day.  When I arrived, I was disppointed to find that instead of having a lunch menu and taking advantage of being the only sandwich place worth eatting at on clement, I saw that all the sandwiches were premade, totaling 4 or 5 options and that was it.  No sides, no salads, no customizations.  Somewhat begrudingly, I picked up the turkey sandwich, but the total was under the $10 minimum for credit card so I had to buy a chicken one too.  To my surprise, the sandwiches were GREAT!  The bread was fresh and chewy, not crusty and hard as it is at most places.  The fixins were all just right and I enjoyed every bite.  I don't know whether to avoid the pastries, or maybe it was just a bad day for Megan, but the sandwiches were a great on-the-go lunch!
author: Jared F.

description: This is a simple bakery, they have a lot of fresh baked goods that are inexpensive and well displayed. You can get a fresh loaf of bread on premises that runs the mill from plain old white bread to something more enticing such as the chocolate cranberry loaf. There are fancier and more expensive bakeries in town, but this place suits the 'hood and is friendly and delicious.
author: Colleen B.

description: Good pastries and great desserts.  Everyone here is always really nice and helpful.  Their strawberry shortcake is really good.  So are their eclairs.  They keep the place really clean and in my book that is a big plus.
author: Stella C.

description: This place is okay, but it's NOT a bakery-at least not visibly.  Like other reviewers I felt the atmosphere was sterile and a bit like a classroom or a cafeteria.  That being said the blueberry pastry I had was so good I ordered another (hence the one star), but my girlfriend's chocolate croissant was so bad she couldn't finish it and the mocha I ordered was undrinkable.  I'm giving two stars for the pastry I enjoyed and the cordial staff.
author: Nate W.

description: Chocolate croissant was meh. The pesto bread was hard and unsatisfying. One can not live on eggplant sandwiches alone....
author: Nadia P.

description: I'm a big fan of their whole grain bread. Unfortunately they stopped making walnut twists. It is a little sterile, but when you want a quiet place, it's nice. I do wish they would add outdoor tables--we need more casual spots on Clement St. to sit outside and enjoy watching the world go by.
author: Daneen A.

description: I had my usual here, a croissant.  Of course I was happy to start my day that way.  This place is pretty sparse, lots of tables.  Not much else to say.
author: Sarah F.

description: Love the bread and danish at this place. Nothing is overly sweet. Very clean feel, and the staff is very helpful. Haven't tried any of the cakes yet. But I'm about to...
author: L K.

description: Not great coffee but yummy pastries and bread place on Clement... Opens early, always a few tables if you need a place to sit and catch up with friends.
author: On C.

description: Changed ownership..the old mean lady is gone.. add two stars. decent sandwiches. Great bread.
author: charles p fa t.

description: I created a Yelp account just to review this HORRIBLE establishment!  I was starving and only had a couple of minutes to grab lunch to go and head back to work---I ordered a salad.  I asked for the dressing on the side.  Before I left I checked the bag and saw to small dressings.  When I opened the salad once I was back at my desk I found a Caesar Salad swimming in dressing with extra dressing on the side!!  HORRIBLE it was completely inedible!
author: likes t.

description:
Nothing but three kinds of bread! Weird.

Big selection of great-tasting pastry, tarts, etc.  Their cakes are among the best in town -- try the dream cake once, and you won't be able to stand the sugar-laden stuff most bakeries produce. 

If you don't like good food, don't like cleanliness, and are addicted to sugar -- this isn't the place for you. 

There are plenty of Starbucks out there for all the folks who just want their usual McCoffee and McBread -- if you want something different, give this place a try.
author: Lynn C.

description: I love this place.  It has a nice big space and tables are very far from each other.  I love its bread, pastries, too.
author: Miinno N.

description: 4 stars for cleanliness and service but the baguette (to eat with my leftover super stinky saint agur cheese) i got wasn't super stellar. it was too soft , imo. anyway, i thought it was kinda neat as i walked out of grain d'or, baguette under my arm only to walk back home to the sound of accordion music from some guy who was playing it on a corner a few blocks down. i felt like i was in some french movie!
author: kristin e.

description: sketchy chicken in their otherwise tasty (although somewhat skimpy) grilled chicken fruit and nut salad. like the kind that's sort of processed and has grill marks on it that aren't from a grill. to me, that doesn't say good things about the quality of their other items. $7.50 not well spent, i ended up picking out the chicken since that sorta thing freaks me out. fruit was good, though. there could have been a few more mixed greens in it.
author: Cathleen M.

description: it's called "dream cake".  you have to order it one day in advance.
author: Rosalee C.

description: I swear I reviewed this place already.  I think reviews on Yelp disappear willy nilly and can't explain it.  Lovely little shop to have on the street.  The people are pleasant and the place is never too busy.
author: Misti L.

description: Though the danishes are not fabulous, the walnut and cream cheese bread is very yummy. Two of the women who work there are really sweet though, so they keep me going back for a snack once in a while.
author: Tami H.

description: i just had the most amazing toasted onion bagel with cream cheese from this place on friday (and i'm a jewish girl from new york)!   maybe it was because i had just come from the gym and was starving...but it was so tasty, i ate it in 4 bites!
author: Cyn B.

description: This is nice, strikingly clean bakery in the Richmond.  Enjoyed my mocha and pesto cheese bread (warmed up of course).  Not too crowded, nice place to study and have some space. I would agree that the prices are a little high, (4-6$ for a loaf of bread, when safeway has some under 3 bucks).  Everyone is nice and there were fresh flowers on the tables!
author: Air Squid S.
